definition:
A triangular arrangement of numbers very similar to Pascal’s triangle.

Begin as you would if you were constructing Pascal’s triangle, with a 1
in the top row, and that row $k$ numbered 0, and the 1’s position $n$ as
0.

$$\begin{aligned}
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccccccc}
& & & & & & & & & 1 & & & & & & & &\\
& & & & & & & & 1 & & 1 & & & & & & &\\
& & & & & & & 1 & & x & & 1 & & & & & &\\
& & & & &\vdots & & & & \vdots & & & & \vdots& & & & \\
\end{array}\end{aligned}$$

Now, for the next value, add up the two values above, but then subtract

$${{\frac{n}{2}-1} \choose {{k - 1} \over 2}}$$

From this forward, do the same for every even-numbered position in an
even-numbered row. Instead of calculating the binomial coefficient, it
can be looked up in Pascal’s triangle.

$$\begin{aligned}
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccccccc}
& & & & & & & & & 1 & & & & & & & &\\
& & & & & & & & 1 & & 1 & & & & & & &\\
& & & & & & & 1 & & 1 & & 1 & & & & & &\\
& & & & & & 1 & & 2 & & 2 & & 1 & & & & &\\
& & & & & 1 & & 2 & & 4 & & 2 & & 1 & & & &\\
& & & & 1 & & 3 & &6 & &6 & & 3 & & 1 & & &\\
& & & 1 & & 3 & &9 & & 10& &9 & & 3 & & 1 & &\\
& & 1 & & 4 & &12 & &19 & &19 & &12 & & 4 & & 1 &\\
& & & & &\vdots & & & & \vdots & & & & \vdots& & & & \\
\end{array}\end{aligned}$$

This triangle was first studied by the Serbian chemist Sima Losanitsch,
but has since been found to have applications in graph theory and
combinatorics.

[6]{} S. M. Losanitsch, [*Die Isomerie-Arten bei den Homologen der
Paraffin-Reihe*]{}, Chem. Ber. 30 (1897), 1917-1926.
